Aw yeah! What's up everybody, I'm Ollie and 
today we are learning all about your favorite

prepositions to and for while watching 
some of my favorite TV series like Suits,

Brooklyn 99, Enola Homes and much 
more! Let's take a sneak peek

Now as an English teacher I often hear my students 
tell me just how confusing prepositions are and

that's why watching your favorite TV series and 
movies is a really good way to master prepositions

as you'll get to see them in real situations. So 
in today's lesson I've invited my student Maria

who has had some difficulties in distinguishing 
the differences between to and for and in this

lesson I'm going to teach her and you one of the 
main uses and the pronunciation of to and for

and make sure you stay right until the end because 
I'm going to test your knowledge with a to and

for quiz. But before we get started I want to 
tell you that every week we help you understand

fast speaking natives by watching your favorite 
TV series and movies without getting lost, without

missing the jokes and without subtitles. In fact 
Peter says that our channel is a killer channel

and since discovering our channel his English has 
revolutionized for the better. So join Peter and

our global community. It's really simple, all 
you need to do is hit that subscribe button and

the bell down below so you don't miss any of our 
new lessons. The prepositions to and for can be

used to express many different ideas for example 
direction, destination, time, goals, benefits,

favor, motivation, reason and so much more. That's 
why our focus today will be on the motive or the

reason for doing something. For example I could 
say I'm here to teach you. Teaching is the reason

or the purpose why I'm here. Or I bought these 
flowers for her birthday. Her birthday is the

reason why I bought the flowers. So how do you 
know which one to use? Let's take a look at some

short clips and I want you to pay close attention 
to the word after the prepositions for and for.
What's the word that comes after for?

I wouldn't say I'm a morning person but I 
can make myself get up early if necessary.
Usually that's for an early meeting at work.
I came here to see you.
She told your mother for your own good.

Now that's not incorrect but we tend to use these 
strong forms when we want to emphasize something
Check out these examples.

If you find it difficult to watch your 
favorite TV series and movies without subtitles

then I reckon you should check out this lesson 
that we made. To watch it after this one

you can click up here and I've also 
linked it in the description below

However, prepositions like to and 
for are usually not stressed

and the reason behind this is because they 
are function words. Function words are the

words in a sentence that don't contain a lot of 
important information. Function words in fact

help to connect the other words together. In 
practical terms, if you don't hear the function

words fully stressed then you're still probably 
going to be able to understand what is being said

when words are not stressed some of the sounds 
can be reduced so the preposition to will become
Now, a nice way to practice is by imitating an

English speaker. Let's try this together. First 
we're going to watch a scene and then after the

scene I'll help you with some pronunciation of 
the reduced form of to and for. then I'll repeat
Then I'll repeat the sentence, and then it will be your turn after me to repeat what I say.
Ready? Let's go.

Now the name of the activity 
that we did is called shadowing

and it's one of the most efficient ways 
to help you improve your pronunciation

and to help you speak more clearly. So I
sent this scene to my student Maria for

her to watch and then I got her to do the 
shadowing exercises. Let's see how she does
What the hell's a paleontologist need a beeper for

What if I told you there's a way that you can 
identify the areas of your speaking that you

need to get better at and you can practice 
it every day? Well there is. Our friends at

ELSA SPEAK have developed a unique app that helps 
learners just like you improve your pronunciation,

fluency and intonation now the best part about 
this app is that you get instant feedback on

every single sound and sentence that you 
produce. And that's not all! You'll learn

a lot more vocabulary, sentences and phrases 
that you'll be able to use in everyday life.

If you want to learn more about the special deal 
that our friends at ELSA SPEAK have made for you

our learners all you need to do is click up here 
and there is also a link in the description below.

So, as promised, it's time for the to and for 
quiz. There's going to be two types of questions:

the first type of question you'll be asked to 
choose between to and for and in the second type

you're going to be asked whether two or four 
is stressed or unstressed. And lastly I want

to thank you for joining me in today's lesson 
and don't forget to hit that like button as

well as the subscribe button and the bell down 
below so you don't miss any of our new lessons.

So this ed suffix can be pronounced in 
three different ways either as a "t" sound

a "d" or the syllable "id". Now the common 
mistake I've seen in my students and

learners in general is over using 
the extra syllable it so they'll say
